Anastasius ruled the Roman Empire from 491 to 518. The wealth of the imperial treasury increased considerably during his reign. He was the last emperor who did not insist on the orthodoxy of the council of Chalcedon and, in his last years, allowed the accession of anti-Chalcedonian bishops to major episcopal sees, such as Severus in Antioch.

A brother of Peter , the bishop of Smyrna . A layman and patrician who was a slave owner who taught the slaves the Psalms and hours of prayers and service. He spent the last 9 years of his life in Smyrna with his extended family.

A sister of Peter , the bishop of Smyrna. A lay woman and patrician who was a slave owner who taught the slaves the Psalms and hours of prayers and service. She spent the last years of her life in Smyrna with her extended household. She outlived her brothers. She was living at the time of John of Ephesus' writing his Lives of the Eastern Saints.
The enslaved persons were owned by the brother and sister of Peter, bishop of Smyrna. They were taught the Psalms and the hours of the prayers and the service.

Anthimus was a sixth-century Miaphysite Patriarch of Constantinople who is commemorated by John of Ephesus in the Lives of the Eastern Saints. Anthimus was bishop of Trebizond in north-eastern Asia Minor when Justinian chose him as new patriarch of Constantinople. Probably on imperial orders, Anthimus approached the leading miaphysites of his day, Severus of Antioch and Theodosius of Alexandria. Because of this, opponents started claiming that he had condemned Chalcedon and entered into communion with Severus. Resistance to him grew in Constantinople and his position became untenable when the staunchly Chalcedonian Roman bishop Agapetus visited the capital in March 536. He stepped down as bishop and, together with many other miaphysites, enjoyed the protection of the empress Theodora until her death in 548.
A tribune who was sent with messages to Severus of Antioch from Antoninus, the bishop of Berrhoea
Involved in a dispute with the monk Isaac that came before Severus of Antioch
The bishop of Berrhoea and recipient of letters from Severus of Antioch

Syriac author of 23 ‘Demonstrations’, known as ‘the Persian Sage’. In hagiography: Aphrahat was known as an anchorite who converted from Zoroastrianism to Christianity and fought Arianism in Antioch .
Bishop of Laodicea
A monk and a presbyter, also an associate of Severus of Antioch

Presbyter of Alexander whose ideas started the Arian controversy Arius was a priest in Alexandria in the early fourth century and a famous propagator of the doctrine that Christ was not equal to God the Father, but subordinated to him, hence this doctrine is called Arianism. He and his teachings were condemned at the council of Nicaea in 325, yet some of his ideas remained influential especially in the east of the Roman Empire and among Germanic tribes converted to Christianity in the fourth century.
A person mentioned in a letter of Severus of Antioch
A prefect who expressed imperial displeasure at anti-Chalcedonian statements

Bishop of Laodicea in Syria and an associate of Severus of Antioch In hagiography: Constantine was a bishop of Laodicea . He was a friend of Severus of Antioch and was present at many of the meetings of the Miaphysites that took place in Constantinople . He was a principal author of the canons of the Miaphysite community from the sixth century.

Constantine the Great the Great was the Roman Emperor from 306 to 307 AD and is honored in Christian memory on account of the Edict of Milan in 313 AD which granted religious tolerance in the Roman Empire.

Cyriacus is commemorated in Abraham, Cyriacus, Barhadbeshabba and Sergius in the Lives of the Eastern Saints by John of Ephesus.

Patr. of Alexandria and Greek Church Father. In hagiography: Cyril of Alexandria was commemorated by the Syrian Orthodox Church as one of the fathers who championed one-nature Christology. Cyril, patriarch of Alexandria from 412 to 444, was one of the most powerful bishops of this time. An influential theologian, he clashed with Nestorius of Constantinople on the question of whether Mary could be addressed as Theotokos (bearer of God). Cyril ensured that Nestorius and his dyophysite Christology were condemned at the council of Ephesus in 431. In the sixth century, he was seen as a champion of orthodoxy by both miaphysites and Chalcedonians. The emperor Justinian, in his theological writings, sought to ensure that the decisions of the contentious council of Chalcedon were interpreted in line with Cyrillian Christology.
A cleric who lapsed
In hagiography: Cyrus II of Edessa was commemorated as the miaphysite bishop of Edessa who closed the School of the Persians and expelled its members in 489 with the help of the Emperor Zeno .
Pseudo-bishop

Diocletian ruled the Roman Empire from 284 to his abdication in 305. He stabilised the war-shaken Empire by nominating co-emperors, a system that became known as the Tetrarchy. In the last years of his reign, after 302, he turned against the growing Christian communities. Later authors like John of Ephesus therefore mainly remember him as one of the most cruel and savage Christian persecutors.
Greek author of theological and exegetical works ( CPG 3815-22), bp. of Tarsus. In hagiography: Diodore of Tarsus is a Greek father who is also venerated by the Church of the East.
Bishop of Alexandria who was involved in the debate about re-baptism of those baptized by heretics

Deacon, poet, and theologian. In hagiography: Ephrem is commemorated as a doctor of the church and theologian. Ephrem's ecclesiastical career was based mainly in Nisibis and Edessa . He was the author of hymns, homilies, and prose. His fourth-century writings are remembered as a golden age of Syriac literature. His vita as recounted in hagiography differs greatly from historical accounts. One vita transforms him into a Byzantine monk, which is nevertheless a tribute to his importance in both the Syriac and Byzantine Greek churches.

Ephrem hailed from Roman Mesopotamia and was fluent in Syriac. He embarked on a military career and served as comes Orientis under Justin I. After the devastating earthquake which struck Antioch in May 526, he organised support for the afflicted population and thereby gained great popularity in Antioch. The people eventually chose him as new patriarch, a decision that was ultimately approved by the emperor.
A monk and presbyter whose ordination Severus of Antioch opposed because he had been married twice
Bishop of Rhinocorura and non-Chalcedonian
An Isaurian bishop under the authority of Solon, Bishop of Seleucia

Bishop of Seleucia in Isauria

A patriarch of Antioch about whom only very little is known, Euphrasius came to the episcopal throne in 521 and was in all likelihood a fierce persecutor of the miaphysites. He was killed in an earthquake that struck Antioch in 526, an end which for later miaphysite authors seemed fitting because of his deeds.

A patriarch of Antioch about whom only very little is known, Euphrasius came to the episcopal throne in 521 and was in all likelihood a fierce persecutor of the miaphysites. He was killed in an earthquake that struck Antioch in 526, an end which for later miaphysite authors seemed fitting because of his deeds.
A chamberlain and correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Archimandrite of the monastery of Romanus
A presbyter of Antioch who assisted Severus in calling the bishop of Berytus to repentence
Deacon mentioned in a letter of Severus of Antioch
A presbyter under Cyril of Alexandria
Bishop of Pelusium criticized by Severus of Antioch for failing to comprehend the spiritual nature of the church
Deacon of Apamea
A count in Alexandria who gave away all of his property to the poor
Greek Church Father, bp. of Caesarea (Palestine), and author of the first History of the Church and first universal Chronicle.

Bishop of Samosata, defender of Nicene orthodoxy against Arianism, and associate of the Cappadocian Fathers. In hagiography: In the Syriac version of Eusebius' Life , translated and commented upon by Devos, Eusebius had already become a Bishop of Samosata when he received a visit from Jacob of Nisibis , who allowed him to build a large church. He ordained priests and Bishops during the Arian controversy and was a good friend of the Cappadocians. He was killed by a blow to the head by an Arian woman.
Author of a letter against Severus of Antioch
A Cappadocian bishop who received a letter from Severus
A cleric accused of wrongdoing by Hilarion and Musonius
A monk who received a letter from Severus of Antioch
A presbyter and correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Deacon of Alexandria remembered by Severus of Antioch as a devout and orthodox deacon
Bishop of Tyana who sought the return of Nestorius from exile

Eutyches was a controversial and polemical monastic teacher active in Constantinople in the early fifth century. He opposed dyophysite (two-nature) Christology, but the precise nature of his own one-nature Christology is uncertain. He was condemned in 448 at a synod, restored in 449 at the Second Council of Ephesus , and condemned again at the Council of Chalcedon where he was championed by the Syriac monk Barsauma . In later theological discussions, Eutyches' one-nature Christology was equally condemned by Chalcedonian theologians and the Coptic and Syriac Orthodox Churches. Eutyches was archimandrite of a monk in Constantinople and opposed the doctrine of the two natures in Christ. He was condemned as a heretic at the council of Chalcedon in 451 for supposedly denying the human nature in Christ.

Eutyches was a controversial and polemical monastic teacher active in Constantinople in the early fifth century. He opposed dyophysite (two-nature) Christology, but the precise nature of his own one-nature Christology is uncertain. He was condemned in 448 at a synod, restored in 449 at the Second Council of Ephesus , and condemned again at the Council of Chalcedon where he was championed by the Syriac monk Barsauma . In later theological discussions, Eutyches' one-nature Christology was equally condemned by Chalcedonian theologians and the Coptic and Syriac Orthodox Churches. Eutyches was archimandrite of a monk in Constantinople and opposed the doctrine of the two natures in Christ. He was condemned as a heretic at the council of Chalcedon in 451 for supposedly denying the human nature in Christ.
Governor of Apamea whom Severus of Antioch accused of taking part in ceremonies conducted by a deposed bishop
Bishop of Antioch accused of receiving uncanonical ordination from Paulinus
Eve is the first woman, according to the Jewish and Christian scriptures and was often included in hagiographical accounts of the Paradise .
Bishop of Antioch
Cleric of Paltus accused of misdeeds in a case overseen by Severus of Antioch
Bishop of Antioch

Bishop of Antioch Flavian represented the see of Antioch as ambassador in Constantinople before being made patriarch of Antioch by Anastasius in 498. He attempted to follow a middle course between adherents and opponents of Chalcedon until he lost imperial support in 512 and was replaced by the miaphysite champion Severus. Exiled to Petra, Flavian died in 518.

Bishop of Antioch Flavian represented the see of Antioch as ambassador in Constantinople before being made patriarch of Antioch by Anastasius in 498. He attempted to follow a middle course between adherents and opponents of Chalcedon until he lost imperial support in 512 and was replaced by the miaphysite champion Severus. Exiled to Petra, Flavian died in 518.

Bishop of Alexandria opposed by Severus of Antioch Gaianus was an Egyptian cleric and follower of the doctrine of Julian of Halicarnassus concerning the incorruptibility of Christ (Aphthartism). He was supported by a considerable part of the population of Alexandria after the death of Timothy IV in early 535; the new patriarch Theodosius was ousted and Gaianus acceded to the patriarchal throne for three months before a military expedition reinstalled Theodosius. Gaianus was sent into exile to the west, probably to Carthage.

Bishop of Alexandria opposed by Severus of Antioch Gaianus was an Egyptian cleric and follower of the doctrine of Julian of Halicarnassus concerning the incorruptibility of Christ (Aphthartism). He was supported by a considerable part of the population of Alexandria after the death of Timothy IV in early 535; the new patriarch Theodosius was ousted and Gaianus acceded to the patriarchal throne for three months before a military expedition reinstalled Theodosius. Gaianus was sent into exile to the west, probably to Carthage.
A presbyter from Minidus who doubted whether those who lapsed into heresy, but were forgiven, ought to return to their former grade in the ministry
Daughter of Anastasia and a correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Claimed to be a bishop and performed illegal ordinations until he was convicted

Greek Church Father, and one of the three Cappadocian Fathers, whose influential writings earned him the title 'the theologian'. In hagiography: Gregory of Nazianzus was a Cappodocian father and doctor of the church.
Greek Church Father. One of the three Cappadocian Fathers, and the brother of Basil and Macrina.

Greek author ( CPG 1763–94). Several of his works were translated into Syriac, the most important of which is a 'Discourse on the Passible and Impassible in God', addressed to Theopompus, whose Greek original is lost (ed. de Lagarde, 46–64; ET in Slusser, 152–73).
A saint commemorated by John of Ephesus

Magister militum per Orientis and uncle of Antoninus, bishop of Berrhoea
A presbyter whom Severus of Antioch asked to settle a dispute in the village of Thelhadin

Bp. of Antioch , martyred in Rome. In hagiography: Ignatius was an early Bishop of Antioch who was martyred under the Emperor Trajan. On his way to his martyrdom, Ignatius wrote letters to different Christian communities whom he knew.
Bishop of Corycus considered unorthodox by Severus of Antioch
The brother of Anastasia
Bishop of Lyons who wrote Against Heresies
A former resident of Emesa ordained deacon of Antioch by Severus
A presbyter mentioned in a letter of Severus of Antioch
Bishop of Apamea whose untimely death was lamented by Severus of Antioch
A scholastic and correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Isaac is commemorated in Isaac (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 109v-110v .

Priest and writer. According to a letter from Yaʿqub of Edessa to Yuḥanon of Litarba (Letter 14; ms. Brit. Libr. Add. 12,172, f. 123r-v), Isḥaq was a well-known priest in Edessa who flourished during the time of the emperor Zeno (ca. 474–91).
Claimed to be bishop of Emesa and ordained priests without the authority of the church until he was convicted
A patrician from Egypt
A correspondent of Severus of Antioch
A monk whom Severus of Antioch describes as deceitful and foxlike
The bishop of Chalcis in Syria
A martyr
A count and correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Resident of Tyre who reported to Severus of Antioch a dispute between the readers of Tyre and their bishop Epiphanius
A tribune mentioned in a letter of Severus of Antioch
Greek author of 2000 short letters.

Bp. of Edessa (542–578) and missionary. In hagiography: Jacob Baradaeus is commemorated as a monk educated at the monastery of Phesilta . During the sixth-century struggle between miaphysite clergy and Chalcedonian bishops, Jacob ordained a separate hierarchy of miaphysite clergy. Because of his efforts, The Syrian Orthodox Church was sometimes called The Jacobite church. He also negotiated with the empress Theodora and Harith, the Ghassanid client king. He was ordained by Theodosius of Alexandria and travelled extensively to revive the miaphysite clergy. Jacob was of crucial importance for the development of an independent miaphysite Syrian church in the second half of the sixth century. Consecrated bishop of Edessa by Theodosius of Alexandria in c.542, Jacob ordained a large number of priests in the following years thoughout Syria, thereby ensuring the survival of the miaphysite movement despite Justinian's policy to install Chalcedonian bishops in every city. He was the most authoritative anti-Chalcedonian bishop in Rome's eastern provinces. His position was such that even Paul of Antioch had to ask for his forgiveness after he had entered Chalcedonian communion in the early 570s. Joh. Eph., EH 4.15-34 treats the last years of his life and his conflict with Paul of Antioch.

First recorded bp. of Nisibis. In hagiography: Jacob was an important Bishop of Nisibis who built the large church of Nisibis. Ephrem the Syrian was deacon under him. He played an active role in the condemnation of Arius. The preservation of Nisibis when Shapur besieged it was attributed to his prayers.
Jacob the Apostle the apostle, known as the brother of the Lord.

Jacob the cut-up was a noble Persian from the Royal City of Beth Lapaṭ . He became a Christian, but he later abjured his Christian identity. His family reproached him, so he confessed his faith before Bahram V and was martyred.
A kometianos and associate of Severus of Antioch

label_en.value: James of the Monastery of the Edessenes

description.value: In hagiography: James of the Monastery of the Edessenes is a wonderworking monk originally from Monastery of the Edessenes near Amida who was commemorated as one of two monks (the other unnamed) by John of Ephesus . He is mentioned as a contemporary who met with John of Tella .
An archimandritess and correspondent of Severus of Antioch

Jesus the Messiah is the central figure in the Christian religion. References to Christ are ubiquitous in Syriac literature and cannot be fully noted here. Jesus is the founder of Christianity, believed to be the son of God and Messiah.
Monastic head of the monastery of John Urtaya
A presbyter; member of a distinguished family in Amida
Scholastic of Antioch whom Severus expresses an interest in ordaining as presbyter
A tribune and a correspondent of Severus of Antioch.
A slave recommended to Severus of Antioch for ordination
Presbyter and archimandrite, and recipient of letters from Severus
A monk accussed of wrongdoing in a letter to Severus of Antioch
Presbyter and archimandrite, and recipient of letters from Severus

label_syr.value: ܝܘܚܢܢ ܒܪ ܐܦܬܘܢܝܐ ܡܢ ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܥܩܝܒܐ

description.value: The son of Aphthonia, archimandrite of Kenneshre
A monk of the monastery of ʿAkiba and associate of Stephen, bishop of Apamea
A presbyter, archimandrite, and stylite as well as a correspondent of Severus of Antioch
John is commemorated in John and Sosiana (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 125v-127 .
Imperial chamberlain under Justinian and associate of Theodore Castrensis
Satrap of Balabitene
A presbyter and logothete
The son of Ammian who requested that Severus of Antioch choose his name
A scholastic of Bostra and a correspondent of Severus of Antioch
A count
A presbyter of Antioch whose death Severus of Antioch mourned
A correspondent of Severus of Antioch
A reader who interpreted dreama and prophesies
Founder and monastic head of the monastery of John Urtaya
A presbyter of Antioch ordained by Peter the Fuller
Bp. of Constantinople (398-404).

Bishop of Antioch John was bishop of Antioch and a supporter of the dyophysite theology of Nestorius of Constantinople. This brought him into conflict with Cyril of Alexandria who condemned Nestorius at the council of Ephesus in 431. Peace between the episcopal sees of Antioch and Alexandria was restored in 433 when John accepted the condemnation of Nestorius.
Bishop of Alexandria
Bishop of Alexandria and recipient of a letter from Severus of Antioch
Bishop of Alexandria Minor and recipient of a letter from Severus of Antioch
Bishop of Constantinople
Bishop of Claudiupolis who attempted to persuade Severus to accept Chalcedon as a condemnation of Nestorius

Monk, missionary, church leader, (titular) Bp. of Ephesus, hagiographer, and historian. Born in 507 in Roman Mesopotamia, John became a monk already in his childhood. Since the late 530s, he mainly lived in Constantinople where he enjoyed good relations with Justinian despite his miaphysite convictions. John earned fame with his missionary campaigns in Asia Minor and rose, in 558, to become bishop and one of the miaphysite leaders in Constantinople. John participated in the debates to find a formula of faith that could be accepted by both the miaphysites and the Chalcedonians. He was a victim of the miaphysite persecution starting in 571 and repeatedly imprisoned until his death in about 589. He wrote the Lives of the Eastern Saints, a collection of hagiographic tales, and a large Ecclesiastical History, of which the third part dealing with the events of the 570s and 580s has been preserved.

Monk, missionary, church leader, (titular) Bp. of Ephesus, hagiographer, and historian. Born in 507 in Roman Mesopotamia, John became a monk already in his childhood. Since the late 530s, he mainly lived in Constantinople where he enjoyed good relations with Justinian despite his miaphysite convictions. John earned fame with his missionary campaigns in Asia Minor and rose, in 558, to become bishop and one of the miaphysite leaders in Constantinople. John participated in the debates to find a formula of faith that could be accepted by both the miaphysites and the Chalcedonians. He was a victim of the miaphysite persecution starting in 571 and repeatedly imprisoned until his death in about 589. He wrote the Lives of the Eastern Saints, a collection of hagiographic tales, and a large Ecclesiastical History, of which the third part dealing with the events of the 570s and 580s has been preserved.
John of Hephaestopolis features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints. He was a leader in the resistance of eastern bishops against the council of Chalcedon.
Bishop of Pergamum
Bishop of Seleucia in Syria, associated with the monastary of Mar Bzy

Bishop of Sura, associated with the monastery of Mar Hanina in Sura John was miaphysite bishop of the town of Sura close to the Euphrates, yet he continually resided in the monastery of Mar Hanina which was located not far from the city. In the schism between Paul of Antioch and Jacob Burd'oyo in the late 570s, he supported Jacob, as is shown in Joh. Eph., EH 4.22.

Bp. of Tella (d-Mawzlat) 519–21. In hagiography: John of Tella was commemorated as an ascetic and Bishop of Tella (d-Mawzlat) who had to flee his see on account of the aggression of the Chalcedonians. Alongside Jacob Baradaeus , he is remembered for ordaining Miaphysite clergy during this time of persecution.
John the Baptist is John the Baptist, son of Elizabeth and cousin of Jesus.
This John refers to John the apostle and John the evangelist, whom early Christians commemorated as the same person.
A promoter of the theology of the Council of Chalcedon and an opponent of Severus of Antioch

John the solitary was a monk of Ṭur ʿAbdin . He might be John, the perfect Nazarite, whom John of Ephesus mentions. He was a monk from Zuqnin near Amida. He was forced to leave his cave on account of Chalcedonian aggression.
Rhetor of Alexandria denounced by Severus of Antioch
A scribe who committed suicide by throwing himself into a river
Monastic head of the monastery of John Urtaya; a teacher and firstrate scribe
A presbyter, archimandrite, and stylite who corresponded with Severus of Antioch
A monk accused by Severus of Antioch of making non-canonical accusations
The apostle, martyr, and brother of James
Bishop of Bostra
A presbyter accussed of taking property belonging to the church of Tarsus

label_syr.value: ܝܘܠܝܢܐ ܩܫܝܫܐ ܘܪܝܫ ܕܝܪܐ ܕܕܝܪܗ ܕܒܣܘܣ

description.value: A presbyter and archimandrite of the monastery of Bassus and recipient of a letter from Severus of Antioch
A monk of the monastery of Cyrus whose sin committed unknowingly was forgiven by Severus of Antioch
A chamberlain who copied a letter of Severus of Antioch
Bishop of Emesa
A presbyter of Alexandria mentioned in a letter of Severus of Antioch

An ascetic living in the region of Edessa . In hagiography: Julian Saba lived near Edessa and practiced extreme asceticism. He had many disciples, and he fought against the Arians for the case of orthodoxy in Antioch.
Bishop of Alabanda

Bp., theologian, controversialist. Julian was originally a collaborator of Severus of Antioch and bishop of Halicarnassus. After the accession of Justin I in 518, he was, as an opponent of Chalcedon, forced into exile and went to Egypt together with Severus. There, he clashed with his former mentor since he argued that Christ's body had always been immune to corruption and suffering, a notion fiercely contested by Severus. This conflict ushered in a lasting split among the miaphysites; the followers of Julian, known as Julianists or aphthartists, remained especially strong in Egypt during the remainder of the sixth century.

Bp., theologian, controversialist. Julian was originally a collaborator of Severus of Antioch and bishop of Halicarnassus. After the accession of Justin I in 518, he was, as an opponent of Chalcedon, forced into exile and went to Egypt together with Severus. There, he clashed with his former mentor since he argued that Christ's body had always been immune to corruption and suffering, a notion fiercely contested by Severus. This conflict ushered in a lasting split among the miaphysites; the followers of Julian, known as Julianists or aphthartists, remained especially strong in Egypt during the remainder of the sixth century.

Justin, commander of the imperial bodyguard, managed to accede to the imperial throne in the chaotic situation after the death of Anastasius in 518. He was originally from the Illyrian prefecture and many Constantinopolitan aristocrats considered him as an illiterate parvenu. At the start of his reign, he changed the imperial religious policy, restored relations with Rome, declared the council of Chalcedon orthodox, and expelled miaphysite bishops such as Severus of Antioch.

Roman Emperor, successor of Justinian and his sister's son Justin II was Roman emperor from 565 to 578. His mental illness increasingly affected his ability to rule and necessitated the installation of Tiberius as Caesar in late 574. Joh. Eph., EH 1-3, remembers Justin as a persecutor of the miaphysites in the early 570s and interprets his illness as divine punishment for his deeds.

Emperor from 527 to 565, Justinian exerted a huge influence on the Roman Empire. Famous for the codification of Roman law and the reconquest of large parts of northern Africa and Italy, he was also theologically very active and suppressed the remnants of paganism and Christian minoritarian groups that were labelled as heretics. He supported John of Ephesus in his missionary campaigns in Asia Minor.
In hagiography: This could be Conon, the bishop of Tarsus , one of many bishops consecrated by Jacob Baradaeus in 543 for the emerging Miaphysite church.

Khosrow was king of the Sasanian Empire and repeatedly waged war with the Roman Empire. He was Zoroastrian and occasionally persecuted the growing Christian minority, as is remembered for instance in Joh. Eph., EH 2.18-22. Yet at the same time, John depicts him, in EH 6.20-21, also as a wise and philosophically interested ruler, an image that is shared by other historians such as Agathias.
A follower of the heresy of Adelphius according to Severus of Antioch

Leo I was one of the most influential bishops of Rome, considerably enlarging the power of the papacy. He acted as leader of his city at a time when the western emperors increasingly became powerless figureheads. Theologically, he is famous as the author of the so-called Tome of Leo, a treatise in which he insisted that Christ be understood in two natures, fully divine and fully human. This view was accepted at the council of Chalcedon in 451, but proved a decisive bone of contention with the supporters of a miaphysite Christology who accused Leo of splitting Christ into two.
Leo ruled as emperor in the eastern half of the Roman Empire from 457 to his death in 474.
Subject of a dispute over place of ordination between Severus of Antioch and Peter of Apamea
Agens in rebus during the reign of Severus of Antioch
A saintly old hermit whom Isaiah claimed as the source of his ordination
Leontius is commemorated in Leontius (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 102v-103v .
Leontius of Tripoli was a martyr. He had been a Roman solider. There was a monastery named after him in which Severus of Antioch was baptized.
A deacon of Antardus accused of contracting a second marriage after ordination
Presbyter of Apamea who wanted to collect interest from a loan to his fellow clergy
Bishop of Rome who supported Athanasius against emperor Constantius who sent him into exile
A presbyter under Severus of Antioch
Bishop of Constantinople who was expelled and replaced by Timothy I
Malka is a monk commemorated in the Lives of the Eastern Saints by John of Ephesus .
Bishop of Damascus
Founder of a religious movement (Manichaeism).
Mara of Beth Urtaye is commemorated in the Lives of the Eastern Saints by John of Ephesus ..
Mara the Solitary is commemorated in Mari the Solitary (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 96v-101v and Add. 14650, f. 182v-186 .

Byzantine Emperor who called together the Council of Chalcedon. After the death of Theodosius II in 450, the influential generals Aspar and Ardabur brought Marcian, a member of their retinue, to the throne. In order to legitimise the new emperor, a marriage with Theodosius' sister Pulcheria was organised. Marcian convoked the Council of Chalcedon in 451 and ruled until his death in early 457.
Early Christian thinker, founder of the Marcionites.
Mari is commemorated in the Lives of the Eastern Saints by John of Ephesus .
Daughter of Euphemia
Maria the Armenian, spouse of Thomas the Armenian
Bishop of Berytus and a Eutychian according to Severus of Antioch
A chartularius who wrote to Severus of Antioch requesting that one of his kinsmen be included among the clergy of Apamea.
Bishop of Sura
A presbyter and monk of Cilicia mentioned in letters by Severus of Antioch
A cleric from Berrhoea and associate of Severus of Antioch
The namesake of Maro, the monastic head of Arʿa Rabtha
A monastic head from Palestine
Bishop after whom a monastery was named
A reader and correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Maron is commemorated in Abraham and Maron (text) in the Lives of the Eastern Saints by John of Ephesus.
A cleric of Anazarba whose poetry Severus of Antioch denounced as immoral
Mary is commemorated in Mary and Euphemia (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 40-45 and Add. 14651, f. 70v-81 .

Mary is commemorated in Theophilus and Mary (text) , a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 7190, f. 333v-336v and Add. 14730, f. 112-121 (mutilé du début) .
Mary the Mourner is commemorated in Mary the Mourner (text) , a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14650, f. 182r-v .
Mary, mother of Jesus, features prominently in all the Syriac liturgical and literary traditions. In hagiography: The blessed virgin Mary, mother of God.
Vir illustris and father of John the Scholastic
Bishop of Constantinople following Nestorius
Scholastic whom Severus expresses an interest in ordaining as presbyter
A presbyter who sought restoration to his office from Severus of Antioch following his repentence for the sin of fornication
A monk and correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Meletius was patriarch of Antioch and presided over the Council of Constantinople in 381.
Resident of Tyre who reported to Severus of Antioch a dispute between the readers of Tyre and their bishop Epiphanius
A chamberlain and then deacon who received several letters from Severus of Antioch
A correspondent of Severus of Antioch
A man described by Severus of Antioch as a critic of the church
Founder of Montanism
Vindex of Anazarba and correspondent of Severus of Antioch.
Bishop of Meloe who brought charges against archdeacon Callistus on the ground that he had bought his priestly order and status
The archimandrite of Tagais and a correspondent of Severus of Antioch

Bp. of Constantinople from 428 to 431. In hagiography: Nestorius of Constantinople was a doctor of the Church of the East. Nestorius was dyophysite patriarch of Constantinople and subscribed to controversial Christological positions. He argued that the Virgin Mary should not be called Mother of God, but only Mother of Christ. Some, such as Cyril of Alexandria, interpreted this as a diminution of Christ's divinity. His opponents eventually achieved that Nestorius was condemned and deposed at the council of Ephesus in 431. He was sent into exile to Egypt where he died about 20 years later. In the later miaphysite tradition, he was portrayed as an arch-heretic who had supposedly divided Christ into two distinct beings, the man Jesus and the divine Logos, who had not been with Jesus from birth, but only infused him at a later point.
Bishop ordered by Severus of Antioch to depose clergy ordained by followers of Nestorius
A hermit whom the messenger of the Emperor Theodosius II visited in order to ask for prayers for the conception of a male heir
A monk of the monastery of Simeon who was summoned several times to answer various charges and accusations brought against him
Bishop of Seleucia in Syria
A presbyter of Rome and a heretic
A presbyter of Alexandria and a correspondent of Severus of Antioch
A presbyter of Caesarea in Palestine and prolific theologian and biblical commentator
Bishop of Antioch
A presbyter and monk
Bishop of Ephesus who rejected the Council of Chalcedonian impiety
A patrician mentioned in a letter from Severus of Antioch
Bishop of Olba in Isauria who, according to Severus of Antioch, abandoned his flock by leaving his see and was eventually deprived
Bishop of Emesa who petitioned Cyril to allow the bishops Dorotheus, Eutherius, Himerius, and Helladius to remain in their sees

Patr. Pawlos’s name (‘of the house of the black ones’) was rendered in Greek as ‘of the black (ones)’ (Melanos, sing., or Melanōn, plur.). Paul, nicknamed the Black, was of Alexandrian origin and lived in Constantinople together with the miaphysite patriarch Theodosius of Alexandria. Theodosius ordained him patriarch of Antioch in 564, but he never was accepted by all the miaphysites in Syria. Paul's position was further weakened in the early 570s, when he temporarily entered into communion with the Chalcedonians. Eventually, his opponents succeeded in ordaining Peter of Callinicum as counter-patriarch. According to Joh. Eph., EH 4.54-57, Paul spent his last years in hiding and his death went largely unnoticed.

Patr. Pawlos’s name (‘of the house of the black ones’) was rendered in Greek as ‘of the black (ones)’ (Melanos, sing., or Melanōn, plur.). Paul, nicknamed the Black, was of Alexandrian origin and lived in Constantinople together with the miaphysite patriarch Theodosius of Alexandria. Theodosius ordained him patriarch of Antioch in 564, but he never was accepted by all the miaphysites in Syria. Paul's position was further weakened in the early 570s, when he temporarily entered into communion with the Chalcedonians. Eventually, his opponents succeeded in ordaining Peter of Callinicum as counter-patriarch. According to Joh. Eph., EH 4.54-57, Paul spent his last years in hiding and his death went largely unnoticed.

Bishop of Aphrodisias Paul was a miaphysite bishop ordained by Jacob Burd'oyo around 558 and appears in the tritheist debate of the 560s. He was pressured into accepting the Chalcedonian communion in 571 and reordained as bishop of Antioch in Caria. He appears in Joh. Eph., EH 1.14 and 2.42-43.
A monk at the monastery of John Urtaya

Bishop of Antioch who was deprived of his see Synod of Antioch because of heretical teachings Paul was a bishop of Antioch in the 260s and a controversial theologian. He taught that Jesus had been born a mere man and been infused with the divine spirit only at his baptism. Denying the innate divine nature of Jesus, he was later framed as a precursor of Arianism and Nestorianism and condemned as a heretic.
The biblical apostle, Paul the Apostle , author of much of the New Testament. In hagiography, Paul is often commemorated with Thecla .
Paul the Mourner is commemorated in Paul the Mourner (text) , a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 26v-28v .
Paul, patriarch of Antioch of Antioch was a Miaphysite patriarch of the sixth century whom John of Ephesus commemorates.
Bishop of Antioch who was charged with the uncanonical ordination of Evagrius as his successor
A monk of Seleucia in Syria charged with bringing his Nestorian brother into the monastery
Presbyter of Antioch and brother of Severus of Antioch
Scholastic whom Severus expresses an interest in ordaining as presbyter
Bishop of Apamea and correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Bishop of Tralles
A correspondent of Severus of Antioch and possibly a presbyter of Alexandria
Peter is commemorated in Peter and Photius (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 127r-v .
Bishop of Alexandria and martyr
Bishop of Alexandria
Non-Chalcedonian Bishop of Antioch

The son of Bosmarios, king of Georgia (Iberia), he was brought up in Constantinople as a political hostage at the court of the Emperor Theodosius II. In hagiography: Peter the Iberian was the son of the king of Georgia. He helped Nestorius preach a homily about the saints. He went on a pilgrimage to Jerusalem and became a monk. He became Bishop of Maiuma in Gaza and was exiled to Egypt in 455.
Bishop of Amasia and a holy man
A monk from Isauria who was ordained deacon by Severus of Antioch
A presbyter, monk, and recipient of a letter from Severus of Antioch who was involved in controversies over reordination and penance
Metropolitan bp. of Mabbug (modern Membij/ancient Hierapolis) (485-519), ascetic theologian, christological polemicist, and sponsor of the Philoxenian NT.
Bishop of Doliche
A chamberlain and correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Bishop of Sirmium whose heresy was discussed at the Council of Nicaea

label_syr.value: ܦܘܛܝܘܣ ܩܫܝܫܐ ܘܪܝܫ ܕܕܝܪܐ ܕܥܘܡ̈ܪܐ ܕܒܩܪܝܐ

description.value: An archimandrite in Caria and recipient of a letter from Severus of Antioch
Photius is commemorated in Peter and Photius (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 127r-v .
A cleric anathematized by Severus of Antioch
An Egyptian monk
Polycarp of Smyrna was an early bishop of Smyrna who was martyred as an old man in the second century. His story became a model for passion narratives of Christian martyrs.
Presbyter of Chalcis in Syria who received a letter from Severus of Antioch
Priscus is commemorated in Priscus (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 122-123v .
A patrician
A correspondent of Severus of Antioch.
Bishop of Colonia
Bp. of Cyzicus and since 434 Patr. of Constantinople.
A holy man discussed by John of Ephesus
Bishop of Flavius whose clergy accussed him of receiving gifts when performing ordinations
A martyr who (along with the martyrs Domnina and Berenice ) threw herself into the waves of the Euphrates when threatened.
Bishop of Alexandria elected by the Council of Chalcedon to replace Dioscorus

Bp. of Edessa (411/2–435/6). In hagiography: Rabbula of Edessa was commemorated as the Bishop of Edessa . He was the son of a rich pagan. As a bishop, he lived an ascetic life, helped the poor, and fought heretics.
Bishop of Rhosus in Cilicia and follower of Julian of Halicarnasus whose ideas were attacked by Severus of Antioch
Romanus is commemorated in Bassianus, Romanus, and Simeon (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 104v-105v .
An archimandrite in Palestine who founded an Anti-Chalcedonian monastery at Eleutheropolis with the patronage of the Empress Eudocia .
Subject of a letter of Severus of Antioch seeking permission from the bishop of Doliche that he might be able to conduct prayers in Antioch
A magistrian who delivered a letter from Master of the Offices to Severus of Antioch
Libyan heresiarch and proponent of modalism
Monastic head of the monastery of Samuel
Monastic head of the monastery of John Urtaya
Archpresbyter of the monastery of John Urtaya

label_syr.value: ܫܡܘܐܝܠ ܩܫܝܫܐ ܘܪܝܫ ܕܝܪܐ ܕܥܘܗܕܢܐ ܐܝܣܚܩ

description.value: Archimandrite of monastery of lsaac
A monk
A presbyter, archimandrite, and stylite who corresponded with Severus of Antioch
Deacon whose ordination was called into question over misappropriation of funds.
A correspondent of Severus of Antioch.
Bishop of Augusta and brother of Julian the presbyter
A syncellus and notary of Amida; sent into exile in Petra
Sergius is commemorated in Simeon and Sergius (text) which features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
A reader whom Severus of Antioch criticized for causing harm by relating dream visions and prophesies
A physician and sophist who corresponded with Severus of Antioch.
A count and archiatrus who corresponded with Severus of Antioch

label_syr.value: ܣܪܓܝܣ ܦܦܐ ܒܪܒܘܬܐ ܗܘ ܪܝܫܐ ܕܥܡܐ ܕܬܪ̈ܝܢ ܗܘ ܕܣܘܪ̈ܝܝܐ

description.value: Governor of Syria Secunda
A bishop and syncellus to James Burdʿana

Sergius was one of the most popular saints of the Orient. He was a Roman soldier martyred shortly after his friend Bacchus since he refused to sacrifice to the Roman gods. Sergius was decapitated at Resafa on the Euphrates . Sergius, often venerated together with Bacchus, was one of the most popular saints in Syria. According to legend, he was a Roman officer who suffered martyrdom in Rusafa close to the Euphrates in the early 4th century. From the 5th century onwards, his shrine at Rusafa-Sergiopolis became a major cult centre for the Arab tribes, as recorded for instance in Joh. Eph., EH 6.4.
Sergius features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
An endoxatatos and the father of Count Anastasius
Sergius features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Scholastic whom Severus expresses an interest in ordaining as presbyter
Monastic head of the monastery of John Urtaya
Bishop of Cyrrhus
Bishop of Cyrrhus who asserted that Nestorius' theology was consistent with the Council of Chalcedon
Monastic head of the monastery of John Urtaya
A deacon whom Severus of Antioch anathemizes for sleeping with his father’s wife or concubine

In hagiography: Sergius of Tella was the successor of Jacob Baradaeus . He accompanied his teacher to Constantinople where he was received by the Empress Theodora . Sergius was a close collaborator of the miaphysite bishop Jacob Burd'oyo. He resided in Constantinople for a large part of his life and was eventually ordained miaphysite bishop of Antioch. However, it seems that he remained in Constantinople where he died around 560. During the last years of his life, he became an adherent of the tritheist doctrine.
A presbyter of Tripolis

Patr. of Antioch , theologian, and prolific Greek author. One of the most influential miaphysite theologians, Severus was originally born a pagan. After his conversion in c.490, Severus became actively involved in the fight against the council of Chalcedon and gained much importance during the reign of Anastasius. He became patriarch of Antioch in 512, but was forced to leave his see and go into exile to Egypt after the accession of Justin I in 518. In 535, Justinian invited him to Constantinople for religious discussions to overcome the divide between pro- and anti-Chalcedonians. However, these plans failed and Severus died in his Egyptian exile in 538.
A cleric ordained by Chalcedonians who sought to be received by non-Chalcedonians
Bishop of Chalcis in Syria
Archimandrite of the great monastery and a correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Simeon is commemorated in Bassianus, Romanus, and Simeon (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 104v-105v .
Simeon is commemorated in Simeon and Sergius (text) which features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.

label_syr.value: ܫܡܥܘܢ ܩܫܝܫܐ ܐܪܝܫ ܕܝܪܐ ܕܕܝܪܐ ܕܒܬܠܥܕܐ

description.value: Archimandrite of Teleda and a correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Polemical writer and bp. In hagiography: Shemʿōn features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Simeon the Mountaineer features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Simeon the Scribe features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Simeon the Solitaire is monk from Amida and features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.

Saint. Born in the village of Sisa near Nicopolis, Shemʿun was the child of Christian parents. In hagiography: Simeon the Stylite was a shepherd who became a monk. He lived first in a cistern, but then later he built a column on which he lived at Telanesios. His pillar and extreme asceticism attracted pilgrims and converts.
A scriniarius and a correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Bishop of Rome who called for a more careful investigation of the dispute between Flavian I and Evagrius
Bishop of Seleucia in Isauria
Sosiana is commemorated in John and Sosiana (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 125v-127 .
Bishop of Caesarea in Cappadocia
Deacon of Antardus and correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Bishop of Apamea and a correspondent of Severus of Antioch
A presbyter of Antioch under Severus of Antioch
A reader and a correspondent of Severus of Antioch
A grammarian and correspondent of Thecla the countess
Archimandrite of Tagais
Bishop of Tripolis and recipient of a letter from Severus of Antioch
A presbyter of Tripolis
Stephen is commemorated in Thomas, Stephen, and Zota (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 45-51 and Add. 14650, f. 167v-172v .
Bishop of Rome who determined that it was not necessary to re-baptize those who had been baptized by heretics
Bishop of Seleucia in lsauria who opposed local non-Chalcedonians
Bishop of Anasartha who was ordained by Severus of Antioch
A deacon summoned by Severus of Antioch

Suzanna is commemorated in Susan (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 14650, f. 178-182 and Rich. 7190, f. 336v-337v and Add. 14651, f. 94v-103v and Add. 14730, f. 121v-125 .
An Isaurian bishop under the authority of Solon, Bishop of Seleucia in Isauria
Monastic head of the monastery of John Urtaya
A countess and correspondent of Severus of Antioch
The first female martyr

Raised as a child acrobat in the circus, Theodora married the future emperor Justinian I in 523. Before her rise to the throne as the wife of emperor Justinian, Theodora was had been an actress, a profession which gave rise to rumours that she had been a prostitute. John of Ephesus remembers Theodora fondly because she protected a large number of miaphysite monks and clerics in Constantinople until her death in 548.
Presbyter and archimandrite of the Monastery of Theodore
Bishop of Tyana and rival of Helladius, Bishop of Caesaria
Bishop of Olba in Isauria and correspondent of Severus of Antioch
A deacon and monk who corresponded with Severus of Antioch

description.value: Presbyter and archimandrite of the monastery of Romanus
Theodore is commemorated in Elijah and Theodore (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 83-86 .
A tribune and notary who corresponded with Severus of Antioch
A monk of Byzantium and brother-in-law of prefects who left his family to become a monk and then wanted to return to the world
A presbyter and archimandrite who corresponded with Severus of Antioch.
Governor of Phoenice and later Vindex of Tripoli
Theodore Castrensus is commemorated in Theodore Castrensis (text) in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Bishop of Antinoe and opponent of the Council of Chalcedon
Bishop of Hirtha
Bp. of Mopsuestia, biblical commentator, author of theological works and homilies. In hagiography: Theodore of Mopsuestia was a Greek doctor of the Church of the East.
Bp., biblical exegete, church historian, hagiographer, and defender of Antiochene Christology against Cyril of Alexandria.
A presbyter of Antioch who Severus of Antioch sent to investigate accusations against the bishop Procopius
Bishop and recipient of a letter from Isidore of Pelusium

Patr. of Alexandria ; leader of the Egyptian and Syrian anti-Chalcedonians. Theodore, of Syrian origin, was abbot of the miaphysite monastery of Rhamnis in Egypt and consecrated patriarch of Alexandria in 575. However, the majority of the miaphysite clergy did not accept him and elected Peter of Alexandria instead, as is narrated in Joh. Eph., EH 4.10-13.

Patr. of Alexandria ; leader of the Egyptian and Syrian anti-Chalcedonians. Theodore, of Syrian origin, was abbot of the miaphysite monastery of Rhamnis in Egypt and consecrated patriarch of Alexandria in 575. However, the majority of the miaphysite clergy did not accept him and elected Peter of Alexandria instead, as is narrated in Joh. Eph., EH 4.10-13.

Theodosius II is an emperor of the Roman Empire commemorated in Cyril of Alexandria and Theodosius II (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 17134, f. 50v and add. 18816, f. 70r-v . Theodosius II ruled the eastern half of the Roman Empire from 408 to 450. His reign saw the start of the Christological controversy and he convened both the Council of Ephesus of 431 and the so-called 'robber synod' of 449. Joh. Eph., EH 5.14, remembers him as the last purple-born prince (his father was the emperor Arcadius) before the birth of Maurice's son Theodosius in 583.
Bishop of Joppa in Palestine, called the Re-anointer by Severus of Antioch because he unlawfully re-anointed converts from Nestorianism
A correspondent of Severus of Antioch
A scholastic and correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Bishop of Alexandria

Theophilos is commemorated in Theophilus and Mary (text) , a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 7190, f. 333v-336v and Add. 14730, f. 112-121 (mutilé du début) .
Presbyter and chief physician in Tarsus
A deacon charged with ensuring proper execution of a ruling of Severus of Antioch
A presbyter of Bostra whose ordination came into question when he was castrated for medical reasons
Thomas the apostle is commemorated as the missionary to India India, and Christians in India call themselves Thomas Christians after his memory. There was cult to Thomas in the city of Edessa .
A presbyter of Antioch and recipient of a letter from Peter, Bishop of Apamea.
Syncellus of Severus of Antioch
Bishop of Dara and a correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Thomas is commemorated in Thomas, Stephen, and Zota (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 45-51 and Add. 14650, f. 167v-172v .
Thomas of Damascus is commemorated in Thomas of Damascus (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 82v-83 .
Bishop of Damascus driven from his see after the accession of Justin I
Thomas was a miaphysite Bishop of Marʿash (ancient Germanicea) . He was in correspondence with Severus of Antioch and was banished to Egypt .
Thomas the Armenian is commemorated in Thomas the Armenian (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 69-73v .
Duke and correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Presbyter, monk at the monastery of Maiuma, and freedman
Bishop of Constantinople and a non-Chalcedonian
Bishop of Alexandria and participant in the Council of Constantinople
Cath. of the Ch. of E. Timotheos was born in the village of Ḥazza (near Arbela in Iraq ).
Miaphysite Patr. of Alexandria 457-60, 475-7.

Bishop of Alexandria and a non-Chalcedonian Timothy was anti-Chalcedonian patriarch of Alexandria from 517 to 535. During his tenure, he welcomed Severus and other miaphysite clerics from Syria who had been forced to leave their sees.

Bishop of Alexandria and a non-Chalcedonian Timothy was anti-Chalcedonian patriarch of Alexandria from 517 to 535. During his tenure, he welcomed Severus and other miaphysite clerics from Syria who had been forced to leave their sees.
Tribunus was a devout layman and ascetic disciple whose life was recorded in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints .
A corresondent of Severus of Antioch
A grammarian and a correspondent of Severus of Antioch.
A monk who received a letter from Basil of Caesarea urging him to refrain from taking communion with heretics
Heresiarch
An archimandritess and a correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Bishop of Philadelphia in Isauria and a correspondent of Severus of Antioch
Presbyter of Antioch under Severus of Antioch and xenodochus

The sister of Justinian and mother of Justin II Vigilantia was sister of the emperor Justinian and the mother of Justin II. She was still alive when her son acceded to the imperial throne in late 565.
Consul and father of Paul the Patrician
Zacharias is a monk who features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
A monk
A deacon and later presbyter admitted to the presbyterate by Severus of Antioch
Recipient of a letter from Severus of Antioch
Recipient of a letter from Severus of Antioch about the adornment of church buildings
Greek author and bp.
Zeno ruled the eastern half of the Roman Empire from 474 to his death in 491. His reign was threatened several times by usurpers.
A presbyter of Chalcis in Syria who received a letter from Severus of Antioch
A presbyter who delivered a letter from the presbyters John and John to Severus of Antioch
Recipient of a letter of Severus of Antioch

Zaʿūra was an anchorite whose life was memorialized by John of Ephesus . He was a stylite saint who famously replaced his teacher, another stylite, when the former was ready to retire. Zaʿūra also travelled to Constantinople in order to advocate for the cause of the Miaphysites before the Empress Theodora .
Mentioned in a letter of Severus of Antioch
Bishop whose death Severus of Antioch mentions in a letter
Zota is commemorated in Thomas, Stephen, and Zota (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 45-51 and Add. 14650, f. 167v-172v .
A presbyter and son of Abraham the Priest
Satrap of Syria and Armenia; father of Thomas the Armenian
Qashish is commemorated in Qashish (text) , a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 120-121v .
